title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code, by repealing the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases and adding new diseases presumed to be service connected. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code by adding new diseases presumed to be service connected, including heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis. Additionally, the Act grants the Secretary of Veterans Affairs the authority to determine additional diseases warranting a presumption of service connection for prisoners of war. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence and recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence and recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. The evaluation includes statistically significant results, replication capability, and peer review consideration. An association between a disease and being a prisoner of war is deemed positive if credible evidence supports it. If recommended, the Secretary must determine within 60 days if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a specific disease. The Secretary must determine if a presumption of service connection is warranted for diseases associated with being a former Prisoner of War. If warranted, proposed regulations must be issued within 60 days; if not warranted, an explanation must be published in the Federal Register within the same timeframe. If a disease is already covered by regulations, the presumption may be removed. Regulations must be issued within 90 days of any proposed changes. The Secretary must issue proposed regulations within 60 days if a presumption of service connection is warranted for diseases associated with being a former Prisoner of War. Final regulations must be issued within 90 days of any proposed changes. If a disease is removed from regulations, veterans and survivors will still be entitled to compensation. The Secretary must issue proposed regulations within 60 days for diseases related to former Prisoners of War. Survivors of veterans awarded compensation for such diseases will continue to receive benefits. The Secretary will consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. Amendments to regulations must be finalized within 90 days.
